Parker writes:
> To summarize, if you wish to extend an existing configuration file you
> should create your own file with the crawl-oder element containing an
> attribute 'extends' whos' value denotes the path to the 'parent'
> configuration file (e.g. extends="../default/order.xml").

Sounds great: should allow us to have large, relatively unchanging
default crawl-orders which are then specialized by short/volatile 
files for individual crawls/test.

> You may then go about redefining elements under crawl order and in general
> everything should work correctly.  The one known limitation currently is
> the resolution of files with relative paths, which (with the exception of
> files specified in the extends attribute) will be resolved relative to the
> child configuration file.

This sounds like the proper behavior to me: the "child" more accurately 
sets the current context, if the parent needs to specify an exact file
it should use an absolute path.

> While this works, particularly with our simple configuration files, it's
> not the greatest.  For example if the crawler were to select all limits 
> (//limits/) and the child configuration file had overridden just the max 
> toes limit:
> 
> <limits>
>   <max-toe-threads value="100">
> </limits>
> 
> only the max-toe-threads node would be visible, even though the other 
> limits had been defined in the parent configuration file and are otherwise 
> accessible when selected by name (e.g. //limits/max-pages/).

The places where this would currently be an issue is in the list
of all Processor modules, and in the list of Filters per module. 
We should note that in such cases, you must override/repeat all the
parents' collections as a group. 

The idea of mixing collections from child to parent is very thorny:
when should a node replace, rather than add to, a node in the parent's
collection?

> For now we should just be conscious of these limitations, but at some point
> we may want to look for a better way.  I would suspect actually that there
> is/will be a project out there that addresses this, as it seems like a
> common problem, or perhaps we'll decide it's worth solving ourselves.

Yes. Two other implementation ideas (neither is a necessary change, I
just want the ideas captured): 

 - Each Node returned could have a backup Node -- allowing objects which, 
   once created, retain a reference to their defining node to take advantage
   of the same inheritence behavior.

 - The inheritance functionality could be in a subclass of a plain
   XMLConfig class -- so that varied uses can be clear about whether 
   they need/intend inheritance or not.

- Gordon
